name: The Critique of Pure Reason
:LABEL: Curriculum
description: A traversal of Immanuel Kant's critiques of pure reason

name: The Critical Method and Kant's Copernican Revolution
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain in 3-4 sentences why human reason falls into contradictions when it pursues questions beyond experience (e.g., the origin of the world, God's existence);State the central aim of the Critique: to determine what reason can and cannot know a priori by examining reason's own faculties;Describe Kant's Copernican Revolution: instead of assuming our cognition must conform to objects, objects must conform to our cognitive faculties;Identify that the critical method establishes both the legitimate claims and the necessary limits of human knowledge;Explain why metaphysics as a science must be grounded in principles that determine the conditions of possible experience rather than claims about things beyond experience
description: Understanding the critical method and kant's copernican revolution: Explain in 3-4 sentences why human reason falls into contradictions when it pursues questions beyond experience (e.g., the origin of the world, God's existence)

name: A Priori vs. A Posteriori Knowledge and the Problem of Synthetic A Priori Judgments
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define a priori knowledge as knowledge independent of all experience and a posteriori knowledge as knowledge derived from experience;Classify 6 given statements as a priori or a posteriori with brief justifications (e.g., '7+5=12', 'the sun will rise tomorrow', 'all bachelors are unmarried');Define analytical judgments as those where the predicate is contained in the subject concept (e.g., 'all bodies are extended') and synthetical judgments as those where the predicate adds new information;Distinguish synthetic a priori judgments (adding new knowledge without experience) from synthetic a posteriori judgments (adding new knowledge through experience);Explain why the possibility of synthetic a priori judgments is the central problem of the Critique, using one example from mathematics (e.g., geometry) or natural science (e.g., causality);Identify that synthetic a priori judgments are necessary for mathematics, pure natural science, and metaphysics to be possible
description: Understanding a priori vs. a posteriori knowledge and the problem of synthetic a priori judgments: Define a priori knowledge as knowledge independent of all experience and a posteriori knowledge as knowledge derived from experience

name: The Three Faculties of Mind: Sensibility, Understanding, and Reason
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify sensibility as the faculty through which objects are given to us via intuition (immediate, singular representations);Identify understanding as the faculty through which objects are thought via concepts (general, mediate representations);Identify reason as the faculty that seeks systematic unity and generates ideas that extend beyond what understanding can legitimately know;Explain that cognition requires both intuitions (from sensibility) and concepts (from understanding): 'Thoughts without content are empty, intuitions without concepts are blind';Describe how sensibility provides the matter of cognition, understanding provides the form through categories, and reason seeks completeness beyond experience;Recognize that the misuse of reason occurs when it attempts to gain knowledge of objects (soul, world-whole, God) independent of sensibility and understanding
description: Understanding the three faculties of mind: sensibility, understanding, and reason: Identify sensibility as the faculty through which objects are given to us via intuition (immediate, singular representations)

name: Transcendental Aesthetic: Space and Time as Pure Forms of Intuition
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define the Transcendental Aesthetic as the investigation of the a priori principles of sensibility, namely space and time;State Kant's four main arguments that space is not derived from experience but is a pure form of outer intuition presupposed by all outer experience;State Kant's four main arguments that time is not derived from experience but is a pure form of inner intuition presupposed by all experience;Explain how space makes synthetic a priori knowledge in geometry possible (e.g., the properties of triangles are known a priori because they depend on the form of space);Explain how time makes synthetic a priori knowledge in arithmetic possible (e.g., counting and succession depend on the form of time);Identify that space and time are not properties of things in themselves but only the forms through which things appear to us
description: Understanding transcendental aesthetic: space and time as pure forms of intuition: Define the Transcendental Aesthetic as the investigation of the a priori principles of sensibility, namely space and time

name: Categories and the Table of Judgments
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain that categories are pure concepts of the understanding (not derived from experience) that provide the framework for unifying sensory intuitions into coherent experience;Identify that Kant derives the categories systematically from the logical functions of judgment (the table of judgments);List the four main headings of the categories with one example under each: Quantity (unity, plurality, totality), Quality (reality, negation, limitation), Relation (substance-accident, cause-effect, reciprocity), Modality (possibility, actuality, necessity);Recognize that categories are necessary conditions for any experience to be possible—without them, no object could be thought;Explain that categories can only be legitimately applied to objects of possible experience (phenomena), not to things in themselves (noumena);Describe how categories provide rules for synthesizing the manifold of sensible intuition into unified representations of objects
description: Understanding categories and the table of judgments: Explain that categories are pure concepts of the understanding (not derived from experience) that provide the framework for unifying sensory intuitions into coherent experience

name: Transcendental Deduction: Justifying the Application of Categories
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define what a 'transcendental deduction' means: a justification showing that categories have legitimate application to objects of experience (not a logical derivation);Explain the central problem the deduction addresses: how can pure concepts (categories) that are not derived from experience necessarily apply to all objects of experience?;Describe the role of synthesis: the activity of combining and unifying the manifold of intuition according to rules (categories);Explain the 'I think' requirement: all my representations must be capable of being accompanied by the consciousness 'I think' or they would be nothing to me;Distinguish objective unity of consciousness (necessary connection according to categories) from subjective unity (contingent association of ideas);State the conclusion: categories are valid for all objects of experience because experience itself is only possible through the synthetic unity that categories provide
description: Understanding transcendental deduction: justifying the application of categories: Define what a 'transcendental deduction' means: a justification showing that categories have legitimate application to objects of experience (not a logical derivation)

name: Schematism and Principles of Pure Understanding
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain the problem of schematism: how can pure, abstract categories apply to concrete sensible intuitions given in time?;Define a schema as a mediating representation—a rule for producing images in time that connects categories to appearances;Give one example of a schema: the schema of causality is the rule of temporal succession according to a necessary rule (cause must precede effect in time);Identify the four main groups of principles: Axioms of Intuition (all intuitions are extensive magnitudes), Anticipations of Perception (all sensations have intensive magnitude), Analogies of Experience (rules for temporal relations), Postulates of Empirical Thought (modality conditions);Explain one Analogy of Experience in detail: the principle of causality states that all alterations occur according to the law of cause and effect;Recognize that these principles show the concrete payoff of the critical philosophy: they structure all possible experience
description: Understanding schematism and principles of pure understanding: Explain the problem of schematism: how can pure, abstract categories apply to concrete sensible intuitions given in time?

name: Transcendental Idealism: Phenomena, Noumena, and the Limits of Knowledge
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define phenomena as objects as they appear to us through the forms of sensibility (space and time) and categories of understanding;Define noumena as things in themselves, considered independently of our forms of intuition and categories—objects of a purely intellectual intuition we do not possess;State Kant's doctrine of transcendental idealism: we can only know objects as they appear (phenomena), not as they are in themselves (noumena);State Kant's doctrine of empirical realism: within the realm of experience, objects are genuinely real and our knowledge of them is objective;Explain why human cognition is limited to phenomena: categories require sensible intuition to have content, and we only have sensible intuition of appearances;Identify that noumena serve as a limiting concept to prevent the overextension of categories beyond possible experience;Distinguish transcendental (concerning conditions of possible experience) from transcendent (attempting to go beyond all possible experience)
description: Understanding transcendental idealism: phenomena, noumena, and the limits of knowledge: Define phenomena as objects as they appear to us through the forms of sensibility (space and time) and categories of understanding

name: Transcendental Dialectic: The Illusions of Pure Reason
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define transcendental dialectic as the critique of reason's tendency to generate illusions when it seeks knowledge beyond the limits of possible experience;Identify the three main transcendental ideas that reason naturally generates: the soul (rational psychology), the world as a whole (rational cosmology), and God (rational theology);Explain one paralogism: the fallacious inference from 'I think' to the conclusion that the soul is a simple, immaterial substance;State one antinomy (cosmological contradiction) with both thesis and antithesis: e.g., Thesis—'The world has a beginning in time'; Antithesis—'The world has no beginning and is infinite';Explain Kant's resolution strategy for antinomies: both thesis and antithesis can be false if they wrongly assume the world-whole is a thing in itself rather than an appearance;Describe the critique of rational theology: the ontological, cosmological, and physico-theological arguments for God's existence all fail because they attempt to apply categories beyond possible experience;Distinguish the constitutive use of ideas (illegitimate—treating them as objects of knowledge) from the regulative use (legitimate—using them as guiding principles for systematic inquiry)
description: Understanding transcendental dialectic: the illusions of pure reason: Define transcendental dialectic as the critique of reason's tendency to generate illusions when it seeks knowledge beyond the limits of possible experience

name: The Achievement and Significance of the Critique
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain how the Critique establishes secure foundations for mathematics and natural science by showing they rest on synthetic a priori principles grounded in the structure of human cognition;Identify what the Critique denies: the possibility of speculative metaphysics that claims knowledge of things in themselves (soul, world-whole, God);Identify what the Critique preserves: the regulative use of transcendental ideas to guide scientific inquiry toward systematic completeness;Explain the practical payoff: by limiting knowledge, Kant 'makes room for faith'—moral and religious beliefs are not undermined by theoretical reason;Describe how the critical philosophy serves as a tribunal for reason to examine its own powers, establishing both its legitimate claims and necessary limits;Recognize that the Critique's central achievement is showing that the conditions of possible experience are also the conditions of the possibility of objects of experience
description: Understanding the achievement and significance of the critique: Explain how the Critique establishes secure foundations for mathematics and natural science by showing they rest on synthetic a priori principles grounded in the structure of human cognition
